November 7, 1999: Fiction
HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is
menaced when an infamous murderer escapes from prison.
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a
witchcraft school.
POP GOES THE WEASEL, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $26.95.) The lives
of Alex Cross and his fiancee are imperiled as he pursues a serial killer at large in
Washington's diplomatic corps.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for
witchcraft.
A WALK TO REMEMBER, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $19.95.) In 1958, a high
school senior in North Carolina finds love with the daughter of a Baptist minister.
"O" IS FOR OUTLAW, by Sue Grafton. (Wood/Holt, $26.) Re-encountering her
first husband, the private eye Kinsey Millhone has to reappraise her youthful
values while trying to solve a murder committed years earlier.
PERSONAL INJURIES, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) A crooked
lawyer joins forces with an F.B.I. agent who has secrets of her own.
TARA ROAD, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $24.95.) Two women -- one from
Ireland, one from New England -- exchange houses for the summer.
HEARTS IN ATLANTIS, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) Five long,
interconnected stories about an America haunted by the Vietnam War.
SECOND WIND, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $24.95.) A British meteorologist
chases hurricanes in the Caribbean and then faces other kinds of storms back
home.
THE NEW JEDI ORDER: Vector Prime, by R. A. Salvatore. (Del Rey/Ballantine,
$24.95.) A "Star Wars" novel.
ASSASSINS, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) The sixth
volume in a series about true believers who confront the Antichrist.
DUNE: House Atreides, by Brian Herbert and Kevin J. Anderson. (Bantam,
$27.50.) A prequel to the "Dune" chronicles, Frank Herbert's science fiction series.
THE LOOKING GLASS, by Richard Paul Evans. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A
clergyman fleeing his past nurses an equally troubled woman back to health.
November 7, 1999
Non-Fiction
'TIS, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) An Irish immigrant gets used to life in
America: the second volume of a memoir.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
HAVE A NICE DAY! by Mick Foley. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $25.) The
autobiography of a professional wrestler known as Mankind.
A MAN NAMED DAVE, by Dave Pelzer. (Dutton, $19.95.) The concluding volume
of a memoir that began with "A Child Called 'It' "and "The Lost Boy."
DUTCH, by Edmund Morris. (Random House, $35.) The authorized biography of
Ronald Reagan, bedecked with fictional passages.
FAITH OF MY FATHERS, by John McCain with Mark Salter. (Random House,
$25.) A family memoir by the United States Senator and former P.O.W.
WHEN PRIDE STILL MATTERED, by David Maraniss. (Simon & Schuster, $26.)
The life of Vince Lombardi.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead,
$22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
THE TERRIBLE HOURS, by Peter Maas. (HarperCollins, $25.) The role a United
States Navy officer played in rescuing the crew of a submarine in 1939.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War
II.
ALL THE BEST, GEORGE BUSH, by George Bush. (Drew/Scribner, $30.) The
former president's letters, diary entries and memos, with commentary.
HITLER'S POPE, by John Cornwell. (Viking, $29.95.) An account of Pius XII's
conduct during the Holocaust.
ISAAC'S STORM, by Erik Larson. (Crown, $25.) An account of America's
deadliest hurricane, which killed at least 6,000 people in Galveston, Tex., in 1900.
GALILEO'S DAUGHTER, by Dava Sobel. (Walker, $27.) The life and trials of
Galileo Galilei, as seen through the letters of his cloistered, illegitimate daughter.
. . . AND NEVER LET HER GO, by Ann Rule. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The
murder of a secretary to the governor of Delaware by an esteemed attorney.
THE WAY WE LIVED THEN, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $27.50.) An illustrated
